fn.p: A positive event following the meeting was the launch of a national policy on viral hepatitis by the Federal Nigerian Government. National prevalence rates of hepatitis B and C are estimated to be 11% and 2.2% respectively. The “Prevent Hepatitis – Act Now” programme reflects the fact that most of the predisposing health risks for viral hepatitis are avoidable through adequate awareness, behavioural change and screening of blood for transfusion. Measures will include increased vaccination against hepatitis B, safe injection programmes, expanded screening and treatment services, harm reduction and moves to prevent stigmatization and discrimination. It will be essential for adequate domestic funding to be assured [ 45].
